Query: Move all files with a certain extension from multiple subdirectories into one directory

Top-3 Similar Questions: so_30307214: Move files from multiple folders to multiple folders in Linux
ul_74911: How to move all files with a certain file extension from subdirectories to a single directory
so_54560297: How to move files from one directory to another using an array
Top-3 Scripts:
so_30307214: cd test
for dir in folder*; do
    mv "$dir/*" "/temp/$dir"
done

so_54560297: #!/bin/bash
declare -a keyword=("*building*")
declare -a directory=("Building")

for i in "${!keyword[@]}"
do
    echo find /run/media/_Incoming/ -type f -name "${keyword[$i]}" \
        -exec echo mv -t /run/media/"${directory[$i]}"/ {} +
done

find /run/media/_Incoming/ -type f -name *building* -exec echo mv -t /run/media/Building/ {} +

Explanations about Options.-t: move all SOURCE arguments into DIRECTORY

so_64690030: #!/bin/bash

SOURCE_DIR=source
DEST_DIR=destination

for txt_file in $(find "${SOURCE_DIR}" -type f -name "*.txt"); do
        new_path=$(dirname "$txt_file" | sed "s~${SOURCE_DIR}~${DEST_DIR}~")
        mkdir -p "${new_path}"
        mv "${txt_file}" "${new_path}"
done

Explanations about Options.-name:
This option is supported, but POSIX conformance depends on the POSIX conformance of
 the system's fnmatch(3) library function. As of findutils-4.2.2, shell
 metacharacters (`*', `?' or `[]' for example) will match a leading `.', because
 IEEE PASC interpretation 126 requires this. This is a change from previous
 versions of findutils.

Top-3 Scripts:
so_64690030: mkdir -p

#!/bin/bash

SOURCE_DIR=source
DEST_DIR=destination

for txt_file in $(find "${SOURCE_DIR}" -type f -name "*.txt"); do
        new_path=$(dirname "$txt_file" | sed "s~${SOURCE_DIR}~${DEST_DIR}~")
        mkdir -p "${new_path}"
        mv "${txt_file}" "${new_path}"
done

Explanations about Options.-p: no error if existing, make parent directories as needed
